column2: I can identify hypothetical student work as correct or incorrect, analyze the reasoning for incorrect mistakes, and make appropriate suggestions for improvement.
I can solve word problems using basic arithmetic operations.
I can convert the ancient Roman/Babylonian/Egyptian numeration systems to modern Hindu-Arabic base ten, and vice versa.
I can compute addition and subtraction of multi-digit base-b whole numbers using non-standard addition and subtraction algorithms.
I can identify uses of the associative, commutative, identity, zero product, and distributive properties of addition and multiplication.
I can generate elementary word problems most suitable for each of the problem structures of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
I can compute multiplication of multi-digit base-b whole numbers using non-standard multiplication algorithms.
I can compute the quotient of two whole or decimal numbers using standard and non-standard algorithms.
I can identify divisibility statements as true or false.
I can determine if a number is prime or composite via the prime testing method.
I can compute the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two numbers using the listing and prime factorization methods.
I can compute the least common multiple (LCM) of two numbers using the listing and prime factorization methods.
I can convert fractions to different forms (including simplest form), and determine if two fractions are equivalent.
I can construct both number line and area models for fractions.
I can, given two rational numbers, find any number of rational numbers between them and, in the case of decimals, place these numbers accurately on a number line.
I can compute the sum, difference, product, and quotient of mixed numbers.
I can solve word problems using proportional reasoning.
I can identify place values in decimal numbers using both numerical notation and English words, and represent decimal numbers using base-ten blocks.
I can convert numbers between fractions, decimals, and percents.
I can order any rational numbers, including decimals, from least to greatest.
I can solve word problems using percents.

I can explain my reasoning for each step of work in solving a word problem with the basic arithmetic operations, in language that supports elementary students' understanding of how to solve such problems.
I can compare and contrast the ancient and modern numeration systems, and explain how they represent values.
I can explain why the properties of addition and multiplication work, in terms that elementary students would understand.
I can explain why word problems are most suitable for particular problem structures.
I can explain why divisibility statements are logically correct or incorrect, using general logic that elementary students would understand.
I can explain why the method for testing primes is designed the way it is, and why it works.
I can explain how to construct fraction models, and how students can understand how they represent the numerator and denominator of a fraction.
I can explain the denseness property of the rational numbers, by using language appropriate for an elementary student, and by using concrete examples.
I can explain my reasoning for each step of work in solving a proportional reasoning word problem, in language that supports elementary students' understanding of how to solve such problems.
I can explain the relationship between place values in the base ten decimal system, and how the base ten blocks help demonstrate that relationship.
